review.title: Towards Normalizing the Edit Distance Using a Genetic Algorithms Based Scheme
review.abstract: The normalized edit distance is one of the distances derived from the edit distance. It is useful in some applications because it takes into account the lengths of the two strings compared. The normalized edit distance is not defined in terms of edit operations but rather in terms of the edit path. In this paper we propose a new derivative of the edit distance that also takes into consideration the lengths of the two strings, but the new distance is related directly to the edit distance. The particularity of the new distance is that it uses the genetic algorithms to set the values of the parameters it uses. We conduct experiments to test the new distance and we obtain promising results.

sections.text: These data types exist in many areas of computer science, such as molecular biology, where DNA sequences are represented with four nucleotides corresponding to the four bases: adenine (A), cytosine (C), guanine (G) and thymine (T). sections.heading: 3 Genetic Algorithms-based Normalization of the Edit Distance (GANED)
sections.text: ED, which we introduced in section 2, was introduced mainly to apply to spelling errors, making editing operations a major component of ED. Although NDE takes into account the length of the two strings, which in our opinion is an important change, it is based on a different principle from ED, which in our opinion means that it loses some of the main features of ED. In this thesis, we present a new modification of the editing distance, which also takes into account the length of the strings. However, our proposed distance takes a completely different approach from that of NDE. Our new distance is directly related to the editing distance. In fact, the new distance is a lower limit of the editing distance.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion and Perspectives
sections.text: This new distance, GANED, is directly related to the edit distance and takes into account the length of the two strings. What's special about our new distance is that it uses an optimization algorithm; the genetic algorithms to determine the values of its parameters. We tested the new distance by comparing it to another distance applied to strings, and we showed how our new distance, GANED, performs better. In this work, the new distance was applied to symbolically displayed time series. However, we believe that other applications may be more suitable for our new distance.
